game.body:
Changing trends: Colours and design trends come in and out of fashion and so designers can create products that can change as the trends do. For example lounge chairs with different coloured fabrics that can be changed or carpet tiles that can be easily replaced in sections rather than the entire room.

Which trends and consumer behaviours can you change as a designer?

Changing behaviour: To help save wasted energy from over-filling electric kettles, a new design encourages the user to only boil exactly what they need by having two different filling chambers. One that holds the water in reserve and the other that actually boils it. A button has to be held down to fill the boiling chamber from the reserved water. This saves energy as only what is needed is actually boiled. It can be seen as one example of a mental model that supports more sustainable behaviour.

Can you think of ways to change behaviour by using mental models in other ways?

Co-Design: Co-design or collaborative design is when designers work directly with a community or stakeholders to collaboratively design a solution. Examples include designing new health services or products for people working with disabilities while working with the people who will benefit directly from the design outcome.

How can we generalize this practice of co-design with end-users? What other examples would you have in mind?

Electronic waste: E-waste or electronic waste policies have been set up in countries around the world to encourage recycling and remanufacturing. Companies who make electronics have to take them back and recycle them when the customer is finished with it. This means the companies must design their goods for disassembly and the ease of recycling.

What are great examples of electronic recycling you have been exposed to? Which ones would you like to see?

Multifunctional: Designers are moving toward a model of multifunctional items - a dress that can be worn in different ways, a jam jar used as a drinking glass, or a ladder that is turned into bookcases.

What are examples of repurposing broken or used items that could be alternatives to throwing them out?

Reducing energy use: Urban dwellers often don’t have access to a yard or balcony on which to dry clothes. They rely on the use of a dryer. There are other solutions for clothes drying that would allow an apartment dweller to reduce their dependency on electricity.

Are there other habits that could be changed to reduce dependency on energy?

Upgrading… piece by piece: Cellphones are replaced every 15 months on average. Laptops are replaced on a similarly short timeline. Often though a few pieces can be changed out to upgrade the technology to something comparable, if not better, than what is being sold on the market.

Are there other examples of items that could be upgraded rather than replaced? How do you think people could be convinced to upgrade?

Sharing economy: Sharing economies have sprung up around big ticket items such as cars. People will buy in and use the car when they need it.
But it should be possible to think about smaller ticket items. How often do you really use your lawnmower or power saw? But when you need them they are really handy to have.

What are some other examples of a sharing economy that could be implemented?

Lengthening cycle: Society is increasingly driven by trends and with companies shortening production cycles it can seem like a project keeping up. One large chain store recently introduced 52 micro seasons rather than the traditional 4 of fall, winter, spring, and summer.How can we encourage people to move away from shorter and shorter consumption cycles?

Upcycling: Upcycling is the idea of turning something that is worn out into a product of higher quality or value than the used item. The average North American throws away 30kg of clothing and textiles each year. One way to upcycle these items is to make quilts or pillow covers from the old fabric.

Are there other things in households that could be upcycled rather than thrown away?

Consuming differently: Moving away from the traditional money based consumption model can lead to more sustainable lifestyles. Try to think in terms of collaborative consumption (sharing, lending, trading, or swapping items), organic food or simply consumption reduction (e.g reducing meat consumption).

How often can you replace buying a product with simply using it without owning it?

Living at home: In day to day life so many appliances and processes use energy. Think in terms of environmentally friendly appliances in order to save energy in private households.

Can you think of ways to reduce the amount of energy that is used or waste that is produced at home?

Creating new homes: we see more and more ultra-low energy buildings that require little energy for space heating or cooling. Think of a house that would be designed to allow natural ventilation, superinsulation through the walls, roofs and floors, advanced windows, heat from the sun or from the natural body heat of the residents, etc.

How creative can you be in eliminating the need for any heater in your house?

Living in the city: Cities of the future will be designed to reduce ecological footprint. Technical solutions can be put in place, but most often, reducing environmental impacts can be achieved through new ways of living: co-working spaces, telework (from home), mixed residential and professional districts, etc.

What would a post-carbon city look like in your dreams?

Moving around: With more cars on the roads traffic congestion is increasingly an issue, not to mention increased emissions. Solutions include more efficient transportation technologies, such as electric vehicles, car sharing, shifting away from private ownership, shifting toward walking, cycling or public transportation, making sustainable modes of transport safer and accessible, etc.

What are some ways transport can be altered to become more sustainable?

Moving less: Decreasing mobility needs can be achieved through an infinite sample of initiatives. Videoconferencing eliminates the need for travelling. Micro-production outlets eliminates the need for centralized manufacturing, etc. Road pricing reduces traffic.

What other ways can you think of in order to reduce mobility needs?

Health & society: Living a healthy lifestyle is a part of a sustainable lifestyle. Some examples include promoting healthy diets and lifestyles (e.g. labelling), moving toward local and seasonal food, promoting walking and cycling

How can we encourage people to exercise, engage in healthy local eating habits, stop smoking, etc.?

Work: Modern society is evolving toward longer and longer work days. This practice is not sustainable when more and more people are looking for flexible working arrangements.

How can we incite a shift toward more manageable work hours and a healthy work/life balance?

Distance learning: New educational software, online learning platforms and a diversified distance learning options are reducing the environmental footprint of schooling and learning.

How can new distance learning practices be improved and disseminated?

Local food: "Food feet, not food miles". Local production and consumption initiatives include creating community gardens, setting up proximity distribution channels or replacing ornamental tree plantings with fruit or nut trees to grow food.

What other ways can be developed in order to promote localized food channels?

Dematerialization: When less, or better yet, no material is used to deliver the same level of functionality to the user. A great example is when digital solutions replace physical processes, such as digital music distribution for instance.

Can you think of multiple situations in which traditional products or services could be digitized tomorrow?

Do it yourself: The process of building, modifying, or repairing something yourself rather than paying someone to do it for you. Think in terms of urban gardening, repair cafes, maker spaces, bike kitchen, etc.

In which areas can you apply a Do It Yourself approach?

Using the “fun theory”: Make behaviour change attractive by making dull actions fun. Recycling stuff, walking rather than taking your car, etc.

Where could you start a “fun theory” approach?

Quality instead of quantity: Fewer products that are built to last

How, where and when can you adopt products of higher quality that will last longer?

Circular Economy approaches: Creating an economy that is a closed loop of use and restoration of products, processes, and systems rather than a linear model of production, use, and waste.

Where does the circular economy make most sense?

Experiences rather than things: Often experiences can have a more lasting impact than receiving an object for example a trip to the zoo rather than receiving a stuffed polar bear

Can you think of great presents that substitute products with activities?

Using the power of the many: How can the power of each person doing a little bit to work together toward a big change be utilized for good? Some examples include crowdfunding and crowdsourcing. Can the internet be used in this process?

In which concrete situations can you mobilize the power of the many?

Changing values and status system: As society evolves so do values. One example includes an increased disdain of ‘gas guzzler’ style automobiles toward solar powered mobility solutions.

What products and services may exemplify the values of tomorrow?

Education: Sustainability issues should be integrated as a central component of education beginning with very young children all the way to adults. Education can be a key driver of change.

How can we make sustainability a central component of our education?

Role of procurement: Procurement is the act of obtaining goods or services. High levels of procurement can be unsustainable though the procurement of cradle-to-cradle goods or sustainable services can help reduce negative impacts.

How can people be influenced to make a switch to more sustainable procurement practices (both products and levels of procurement)?
